new_evidence.evidence_text: Soviet topographic maps from 1980s at 1:50,000 scale, each covering ca 400 sq km, contained symbols averaging 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), ranging 50-400 per tile
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km. We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2). Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

new_evidence.evidence_text: Maps of Yambol region contained 1,000+ targeted symbols
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: We knew that the maps of the Yambol region contained 1,000+ of these targeted symbols.

new_evidence.evidence_text: Students came from range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities, most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Pődör, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

new_evidence.evidence_text: In 2010 volunteer approach with ArcGIS was unsuccessful - novices found desktop GIS challenging, many quit, those continuing required ongoing support, volunteer attrition + staff demands rendered approach unsuccessful
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS. Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support. In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

new_evidence.evidence_text: 2017 field season was short with little time for student training
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

new_evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile worked offline, met functional requirements for geospatial software, allowed testing of usability approaches from kinetic fieldwork
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria. Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required. In our experience, digitisation work associated with archaeological research often proceeds under such conditions. Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software.

new_evidence.evidence_text: Only 2 of 12 students brought computers but all had mobile devices
new_evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

new_claims.claim_text: The minimally resourced digitisation effort was unexpectedly successful
new_claims.verbatim_quote: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort, as well as the resulting dataset's value for archaeological research and cultural heritage management.

new_claims.claim_text: Compared to manual digitisation using desktop GIS, the approach required little training/supervision, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced large accurate analysis-ready dataset
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

new_claims.claim_text: The approach complements ML in requiring less technical expertise, time, and resourcing
new_claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

new_claims.claim_text: The approach is suitable for projects with small to mid-sized data sources (100s-10,000s of features) that don't warrant ML investment, and for exploratory work or training data production
new_claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction - as well as for exploratory work preceding automated analyses or the production of the training and quality assurance datasets needed for ML.

new_claims.claim_text: The approach focused on implementing tools to empower volunteers to digitise independently with minimal training and supervision
new_claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently. Our approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively for the duration of each field season with minimal support or frustration.

new_claims.claim_text: Decision to use mobile software and FAIMS Mobile was based on: offline capability, functional requirements for geospatial software, testing usability approaches from fieldwork, platform reuse, student touch-screen preference, reduced hardware/licensing competition, and open-source transparency
new_claims.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors.
